predictions: Zully Broussard's altruistic kidney donation triggered a six-person transplant chain.  Software quickly matched incompatible donor-recipient pairs, enabling six surgeries and removing one patient from the deceased donor list.

From a shaky start with rule adaptations and financial losses, MLS has grown significantly in 20 years.  Increased attendance, lucrative TV deals, and the arrival of global stars signal a bright future, though challenges like salary caps and player development remain.

Bafetimbi Gomis fainted during a Swansea match due to low blood pressure, a recurring issue.  He received treatment and is now fine, attributing the incident to stress related to his father's health.  Swansea was aware of his condition prior to signing him.

Frustrated after hitting his ball into the water, world No. 1 golfer Rory McIlroy threw his 3-iron into the lake as well.  He finished the round at one-under, eight shots behind leader JB Holmes, admitting his frustration stemmed from on-course inconsistencies.

13-year-old Cayman Naib is missing from the Radnor-Wayne, PA area since Wednesday. Upset over a school email, he left home without his wallet or waterproof clothing.  Hundreds of volunteers and Civil Air Patrol are searching.  His family pleads for his safe return.

Curt Schilling publicly shamed Twitter trolls who sexually harassed his daughter after he congratulated her college acceptance.  He exposed them, leading to job loss and suspension for some, highlighting online accountability and parental protectiveness.

Two American women were arrested in Rome for carving their initials into the Colosseum.  This follows similar incidents involving tourists defacing the landmark, highlighting a global issue of inappropriate tourist behavior at historical sites.

Prince and 3rdEyeGirl are bringing their Hit & Run Tour to Louisville, Kentucky, on March 14th.  Tickets go on sale March 9th. The venue will be announced later, similar to the 2014 UK tour.  Part of the proceeds will benefit local charities.

A shooting at a Bamako bar killed five, including French and Belgian citizens.  Al-Murabitun claimed responsibility, citing retaliation.  The attack highlights ongoing instability and counter-terrorism efforts in Mali.

Jonny Evans and Papiss Cisse face FA charges for allegedly spitting at each other during a match.  Video evidence, though missed by officials, shows the incident.  Both players deny intentional spitting and could receive six-game bans if found guilty.

CNN Student News on March 10, 2015, covered a solar-powered plane's circumnavigation attempt, mysterious Siberian craters, and a unique view of Mount Everest.  The transcript is available online, and students 13+ can request a roll call mention by commenting with their school information.

ISIS-affiliated militants kidnapped nine foreign oil workers, including four Filipinos and an Austrian, from Libya's Al-Ghani oil field after setting it on fire.  The Libyan government blames ISIS, and Austria confirmed its citizen is held by ISIS "terrorists."

Wichita high school principal Sherman Padgett was tricked into holding a bucket, which students filled with thank-you notes.  Senior Emily Jones organized the prank to show appreciation for Padgett, who was deeply touched by the gesture.

Comic book artist Norman Lee, 47, is presumed lost after disappearing while snorkeling in the Cayman Islands.  Strong currents hampered search efforts, which have transitioned to a recovery mission.  Friends and colleagues expressed condolences and paid tribute to his talent.

CNN Student News, airing March 9, 2015, covered anniversaries of the Selma march, a Malaysia Airlines disappearance, and International Women's Day, along with U.S. unemployment figures.  Teachers and students 13+ could request a Roll Call mention by commenting with their school information.
Jessie Usher (son of Will Smith's character) and Liam Hemsworth join Jeff Goldblum in "Independence Day 2," directed by Roland Emmerich.  The sequel releases June 2016, 20 years after the original.

87-year-old Walter Mondale was released from the Mayo Clinic after being treated for flu and cold symptoms.  He was admitted after a routine check-up revealed a fever.  Former President Jimmy Carter relayed that Mondale was recovering well.
Kyle Waring is selling Boston snow online for $89 (6 pounds) and $119 (10 pounds), capitalizing on record snowfall.  He's shipped over 133 boxes, mostly to companies in warmer climates as a novelty.

Displaced Syrian, Iraqi, and Palestinian refugee women in Zarqa, Jordan, face hardship but find hope through entrepreneurial initiatives.  Despite legal barriers and cultural challenges, they gain financial independence and support each other, demonstrating resilience while needing further aid and empowerment.

Real Madrid lost 1-0 to Athletic Bilbao, thanks to Aduriz's header.  Real struggled offensively, failing to score from open play in two games.  This loss allows Barcelona to potentially take the La Liga lead. Bilbao celebrated its first win against Real in five years.

In Sumoto, Japan, a 40-year-old man has confessed to fatally stabbing five neighbors, three women and two men.  The victims lived near the suspect, possibly sharing his surname.  Police are investigating the motive.

In Lashkar Gah, Afghanistan, a suicide car bombing near a police vehicle killed seven and injured 23, including several children. Most casualties were civilians.  The attacker's identity and motive remain unknown.

Pakistan's Supreme Court ordered the release of Zaki-ur-Rehman Lakhvi, the alleged mastermind of the 2008 Mumbai attacks, deeming his detention illegal.  India condemned the decision, expressing strong disapproval over the release of the Lashkar-e-Taiba leader.

In a metro Atlanta apartment complex, a white police officer fatally shot an unarmed, naked African-American man who charged at him.  The man, a complex resident, was possibly experiencing a mental health crisis.  The incident is under independent investigation.

A viral photo shows a weasel clinging to a flying woodpecker near London.  Amateur photographer Martin Le-May captured the unusual struggle, with the weasel eventually losing its grip. Experts believe the weasel, though ambitious, likely couldn't subdue the larger bird.

Following inflated resale prices of Kanye West's Yeezy sneakers, eBay is now flooded with joke listings of "Kanye concert air" in bags.  Some listings even include "air-infused" items, while actual Yeezy Boost sneakers are being resold at exorbitant prices, contradicting West's desire for affordability.

A Delta flight skidded off a LaGuardia runway after landing in snowy conditions. The crew reported brake issues despite maximum auto brake setting and deployed spoilers manually.  The NTSB is investigating the cause, including weather conditions.

107 schools in Pakistan's Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province have been renamed to honor the 132 children killed in the December 2014 Taliban attack on Peshawar's Army Public School.  This gesture commemorates the students' bravery during the siege.

Leveraging the viral #thedress debate, South Africa's Salvation Army created an ad featuring a bruised woman in a white/gold version to raise awareness about domestic violence, asking "Why is it so hard to see black and blue?"

NASCAR reinstated Kurt Busch after lifting his indefinite suspension for alleged domestic violence.  Delaware declined to press charges, and Busch completed NASCAR's reinstatement program. He remains on indefinite probation and must continue treatment.

Confusion and delays plagued the initial response to MH370's disappearance.  Communication failures between air traffic control and a delayed distress signal hampered search efforts.  Radar data was also not effectively utilized, leading to a significantly delayed search expansion.
In Myanmar, a ferry capsized near Sittwe due to a large wave, resulting in 21 deaths and 21 missing.  At least 167 people were rescued.  This follows other recent fatal ferry accidents in the region.

Myanmar warplanes bombed a Chinese sugarcane field, killing four and wounding nine. China responded with fighter jet patrols and summoned Myanmar's ambassador, demanding investigation and justice.  Cross-border fighting between Myanmar forces and rebels prompted the incident.

Self-diagnosing online can lead to misinformation and unnecessary anxiety.  Use reputable sites, be wary of forums, avoid emotional reasoning, share your research with your doctor, and don't delay seeking professional medical help when needed.

19-year-old Erich Nowsch Jr. was indicted for the murder of Tammy Meyers.  Nowsch allegedly shot Meyers after a road rage incident escalated into a chase and shootout involving Meyers, her son, and Nowsch. Nowsch claims self-defense.

Racial tensions, fueled by police shootings and protests, necessitate improved police-community relations.  Building trust requires community engagement in policing policies, increased foot patrols, and fostering mutual respect through shared activities.

A North Korean diplomat in Bangladesh was caught smuggling 27kg of undeclared gold.  Bangladesh protested, and the diplomat, after initially resisting the search, left the country.  It's unclear if this was personal corruption or sanctions-related.

Baby Lily, found hanging upside down in her car submerged in a Utah river for nearly 14 hours, is recovering well. Her mother died in the crash.  Her father, Deven Trafny, is grateful for her survival and calls it a miracle.

A medical helicopter with three EagleMed employees crashed Thursday near Eufaula, Oklahoma, en route from Tulsa to McAlester.  The FAA is investigating.  This follows a separate Black Hawk crash earlier this week in Florida, where 11 service members are presumed dead.

Monohm's Runcible, a circular "anti-smartphone," challenges the rectangular dominance in digital devices.  Its unique form aims to promote a calmer, less distracting digital experience, prompting a rethinking of interface design and user interaction.

Moff Mors, a lesbian Imperial official, will be the first openly gay character in the official Star Wars canon, appearing in the upcoming novel "Lords of the Sith," confirmed by Del Rey editor Shelly Shapiro.

In Lahore, Pakistan, two suicide bombings claimed by the Pakistani Taliban killed 14 and wounded 78 at a Christian church.  The attack highlights the ongoing persecution of religious minorities in Pakistan and the Taliban's renewed commitment to violence.

A massive IRS impersonation scam has swindled over 3,000 victims out of $15 million since 2013. Scammers, believed to be operating from India, use victims' financial information to convincingly demand immediate payment, often threatening arrest.  Authorities urge anyone receiving such calls to hang up and report the incident.

Republicans' attempts to undermine Obama's Iran deal, though extraordinary, aren't historically unique.  Past actions by Kennedy and Nixon, involving the Soviets and Vietnam respectively, demonstrate that partisan foreign policy maneuvering, even challenging executive authority, has precedents.

Pope Francis, two years into his papacy, told Televisa he anticipates a short reign, possibly just a few more years.  He enjoys his role and visiting his predecessor, but misses the anonymity of everyday life.  He also announced a "Jubilee of Mercy" starting December 2015.

Ashton Kutcher's Facebook post highlighted the lack of diaper changing tables in men's restrooms, sparking discussion about gender equality and parenting.  Many praised Kutcher for raising the issue, while others suggested family restrooms or specific businesses as solutions.

Spain's Caminito del Rey, a perilous cliffside path closed for over a decade, reopens March 26 after extensive renovations.  The 7.7km trail, featuring a boardwalk 100 meters above a river, will be free for six months.  Reservations are required.

Isaac Herzog, leader of the Zionist Union, is challenging Benjamin Netanyahu in the upcoming Israeli elections.  Herzog, campaigning on social reform and collaboration with international allies, aims to restart peace talks with Palestinians and prevent a nuclear Iran.  Polls show a tight race.

Brazilians protested President Rousseff's leadership amid a corruption scandal involving Petrobras, the state oil company she once chaired.  While Rousseff isn't implicated, protesters cite the scandal and a struggling economy as reasons for her impeachment.  Rousseff acknowledges the protests and vows to fight corruption.

Sixteen Indonesians, including men, women, and children, were detained in Gaziantep, Turkey, for attempting to cross into Syria.  Indonesian officials are investigating and cooperating with Turkish authorities. This incident is separate from another group of 16 Indonesians missing in Turkey.

A Tamil news station in India was bombed after Hindu groups protested its planned program on the mangalsutra/thaali necklace.  This attack, along with other recent censorship incidents, highlights growing intolerance and threats to free speech in India despite constitutional guarantees.

Serena Williams returns to Indian Wells after a 14-year boycott following racist abuse in 2001.  While Venus continues her boycott, Serena seeks closure, prioritizing her heart and integrity despite past trauma.  Tournament organizers welcome her return, hoping to mend a painful chapter.

Kick It Out's mobile app has seen a 35% rise in fan-reported racist, discriminatory, and abusive behavior in English football.  The app's anonymity encourages reporting, leading to FA investigations and sanctions, including fan suspensions and social media account deletions.  Video evidence is proving crucial in identifying offenders.

Michelle Carter's involuntary manslaughter case highlights the need for parents to be aware of teens' legal rights.  Author Lisa Green advises parents to have a criminal defense lawyer in mind and understand potential legal ramifications of teen actions, especially in the digital age and regarding school policies and social host laws.

Photographer Ignacio Evangelista's "After Schengen" project documents abandoned European border checkpoints, remnants of a pre-open border era.  His photos capture these ghostly structures, reflecting on the changing political landscape and human impact of once heavily fortified frontiers.

Daniel Ricciardo, reflecting on his disqualification from the 2014 Australian Grand Prix for a fuel flow infringement, acknowledges F1's unpredictable nature. Despite past setbacks, he embraces the challenge and anticipates his home race, aiming for redemption.

Disney's "Cinderella" charmed audiences with a $70.1 million opening weekend, surpassing expectations and "Maleficent's" debut.  Liam Neeson's "Run All Night" underperformed.  "It Follows" impressed in limited release. "Kingsman" crossed $100 million domestically.

Harper Lee's "Go Set a Watchman," a prequel to "To Kill a Mockingbird," is set for July release despite concerns about the 88-year-old author's mental capacity.  An Alabama investigation concluded Lee consented to publication, closing the elder abuse inquiry.

A photo of a sailor cradling a newborn in an American flag sparked debate about patriotism versus flag desecration. While some criticized it as disrespectful, others, including veterans, found it a beautiful representation of service and family.  The photographer, a Navy wife, continues to take similar photos despite criticism.

Candida Moss, a professor at the University of Notre Dame, answered viewer questions about the CNN series "Finding Jesus."  She clarified the significance of the number 40 in the Bible, discussed the relationship between Jesus and John the Baptist, and addressed the limitations of DNA analysis on ancient relics.

Smartwatches offer convenient information access and some health benefits, but also foster a "phantom device effect," compulsive checking, and privacy concerns.  Over-reliance on biodata may promote self-obsession and anxiety, replacing meaningful social interaction with personal wellness tracking.

Following Robert Durst's murder charge for Susan Berman's death, police raided his Houston condo.  His lawyer called the search, 15 years after the crime, "ridiculous." Durst remains jailed in New Orleans on separate drug and weapons charges.

Hate groups in the US declined for the second consecutive year, reaching their lowest point since 2005. While KKK chapters drastically decreased, some may have gone underground.  The rise of online hate forums and "lone wolf" actors remains a concern.

Reverend Fred Craddock, renowned preacher and preaching scholar, died at 86.  He revolutionized preaching with his inductive, conversational style, impacting countless preachers and congregations.  Craddock's legacy extends beyond the pulpit to his compassionate work with the Craddock Center, serving underprivileged children.

Hillary Clinton's exclusive use of a private email server during her tenure as Secretary of State is under scrutiny.  The State Department only recently began automatically archiving emails, despite Clinton's claim that her communications were being preserved.  Republicans are demanding access to Clinton's server to ensure all public records are accounted for.

Two more American aid workers exposed to Ebola in Sierra Leone returned to the US for monitoring, joining eight others.  One worker, hospitalized in critical condition, prompted the returns.  While some monitored individuals are isolated, none of the returnees have tested positive for Ebola.

Danny Welbeck's goal against his former club, Manchester United, secured a 2-1 FA Cup quarter-final win for Arsenal.  Di Maria's red card for grabbing the referee compounded United's woes. Arsenal advances to the semi-finals to face Reading or Bradford.

Loistine Hoskin's experience with Ferguson's discriminatory ticketing and fines, culminating in a $1,200 loss over a towed car, exemplifies the Justice Department's findings of racially biased revenue generation by the city's police, courts, and administration.

After a week's absence sparking health rumors, the Kremlin released photos and video of Putin meeting with Russia's Supreme Court head.  Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov dismissed the rumors, attributing them to "spring fever."

PSG overcame Zlatan Ibrahimovic's red card and a late Chelsea penalty to draw 2-2 and advance to the Champions League quarterfinals on away goals. Thiago Silva, after conceding the penalty, scored the decisive equalizer.  Bayern Munich routed 10-man Shakhtar Donetsk 7-0 in the other match.

Five Chelsea fans have been summoned to court for allegedly racist chanting and preventing a black man from boarding a Paris metro train.  They face potential football banning orders of up to ten years.  Chelsea condemned the incident and suspended the individuals.

Sotheby's is auctioning Maurizio Cattelan's $900,000 granite sculpture listing every England football defeat from 1874-1998.  The satirical artwork, a memorial to English football failures, is on display until March 10th.

Tens of thousands rallied in Tel Aviv against Netanyahu's government, demanding change on the two-state solution and cost of living.  Led by a grassroots movement, the rally encouraged voters to oust the current administration in the upcoming elections, though no specific party was endorsed.

Cleveland's Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Induction Ceremony on April 18th will feature star-studded presenters like Paul McCartney and Patti Smith, and performances by Beck and John Legend.  The event, honoring seven inductees including Ringo Starr and Green Day, will air on HBO May 30th.

Tairod Nathan Webster Pugh, a U.S. Air Force veteran, pleaded not guilty to terror-related charges. He's accused of attempting to join ISIS in Syria, but was deported from Turkey.  Evidence includes a pro-ISIS letter and border crossing charts found on his laptop.

Silicon Valley, contrary to popular belief, is destroying jobs, not creating them, leaving millennials underemployed and financially insecure.  The "sharing economy" offers low-paying, unstable gigs, while automation threatens even more jobs.  Action is needed to hold tech companies accountable and protect workers.

Divers are recovering artifacts from the scuttled CSS *Georgia* in Savannah.  Initial finds include leg irons, cannon parts, and personal items.  The wreck's recovery is necessary for a harbor deepening project.  Conservation efforts will preserve the artifacts for eventual display.

Concerned about dangerous driving by tourists, New Zealanders have been snatching keys from foreign drivers.  Authorities condemn this vigilantism, while acknowledging rising tourist-involved accidents, especially in scenic South Island areas.  The government is implementing road improvements and educational campaigns.

Cyclone Pam, a Category 4 storm, devastated Vanuatu's capital, Port Vila, with 190 mph winds and torrential rain.  The storm caused widespread destruction, leaving many homeless and in urgent need of shelter, food, and water.  Relief efforts are underway.

Esfahan's Jewish community of 1,500 practices openly, with 13 synagogues and businesses.  Despite Iran's hostility towards Israel, they identify as Iranian Jews and feel integrated, though some abroad express concern.

Israel's upcoming election offers negligible policy difference regarding Palestine.  Both Netanyahu and Herzog intend to maintain control, differing only in rhetoric.  Economic issues and scandals dominate the campaign, while the occupation remains unaddressed.

Turkish TV aired video allegedly showing three British girls, resembling missing London teens, at the Turkey-Syria border on February 19th.  The video suggests they were assisted crossing into Syria, likely to join ISIS.  The girls' families have pleaded for their return.

Kerry Washington will star as Anita Hill in HBO's "Confirmation," a TV movie about the 1991 Clarence Thomas Supreme Court hearings.  Susannah Grant is writing the script, and Rick Famuyiwa is in talks to direct.  The film will be produced by Groundswell Productions and ABC Signature Studios.

47 Republican senators sent a letter to Iran seemingly undermining President Obama's nuclear negotiations, sparking accusations of disrespect and unconstitutional behavior.  This act, along with past incidents, highlights a pattern of Republican hostility towards Obama, potentially fueled by racial bias.

CNN interviewed Prince Charles at Birkhall, his Scottish home, for a special on his 10th wedding anniversary.  Camilla, though not interviewed, welcomed the crew and appeared in footage.  The interview offered a glimpse into the couple's close relationship.

A black UVA student's bloody arrest by alcohol control agents sparked protests and a state investigation.  Student leaders organized a forum with law enforcement to discuss police brutality and community relations, amidst national debate on police use of force.

Kelly Gissendaner, a death row inmate, found faith and transformed her life through theological studies.  Despite facing execution, she embodies hope and redemption, prompting calls for clemency and challenging the meaning of forgiveness.

Watertown police recounted the shootout with the Boston Marathon bombing suspects.  Tamerlan Tsarnaev was killed after being shot and run over by his brother, Dzhokhar, who escaped but was later captured.  Officers described a chaotic scene with gunfire, explosives, and a near-fatal friendly fire incident.

Eleven service members are believed dead after an Army Black Hawk helicopter crashed in Florida during a training exercise in dense fog.  The search has shifted to recovery efforts, focusing on retrieving the wreckage and remains.  The cause of the crash is under investigation.

The bodies of four Italian tourists killed in the Bardo Museum attack returned to Italy.  The investigation continues with nine arrests made.  Two suspects, trained in Libya, were identified, and ISIS claimed responsibility.  Fourteen victims remain unidentified.

Ferguson residents are initiating a recall against Mayor James Knowles following a DOJ report exposing institutional racism.  This comes after the police chief and city manager resigned, and amidst ongoing protests and the recent shooting of two officers.

Ozgecan Aslan's murder on a Turkish bus sparked national protests over violence against women.  Her death highlighted the country's cultural and criminal issues regarding women's safety, prompting calls for legal reforms and inspiring her family to establish a rehabilitation center for male abusers.

Lindsey Vonn won a record 65th World Cup super-G, taking the discipline lead.  While trailing in the overall standings, she aims for two discipline titles at the finals. Kjetil Jansrud secured the men's super-G title.

Sex trafficking of children is a pervasive problem in the US.  Two bills, the JVTA and SETT, aim to support victims, strengthen law enforcement against traffickers, and ensure minors are treated as victims, not criminals.

Following a deadly terrorist attack at the Bardo Museum, a social media campaign using "#IWillComeToTunisia" aims to support the country's vital tourism industry.  People globally are pledging to visit, defying fear and showing solidarity with Tunisia.

Retired Wimbledon champion Marion Bartoli is considering a return to professional tennis, sparking discussion and advice from figures like Jimmy Connors.  Bartoli's potential comeback follows other veteran players who rejoined the tour after retirement.

Liza Minnelli, 68, has entered rehab for substance abuse treatment, according to her spokesman.  She is reportedly making excellent progress.  Minnelli has publicly battled addiction to alcohol and painkillers in the past.

Zaur Dadayev, the primary suspect in Boris Nemtsov's murder, retracted his confession, claiming torture and threats.  Human rights activists visiting him face questioning, sparking criticism about the investigation's fairness.  Other suspects also deny involvement.

Ferguson, Missouri seeks a new police chief to mend community-police relations after Michael Brown's shooting.  Sanford, Florida's chief, Cecil Smith, suggests the ideal candidate needs empathy, confidence, and passion, like he employed rebuilding trust after Trayvon Martin's death.  Finding the right person will be challenging given the city's deep racial tensions.

March Madness, the NCAA basketball tournament, pits big programs against smaller schools.  Its high-profile stage offers NBA prospects, especially from smaller schools, a chance to shine before scouts and millions of viewers.  Valparaiso coach Bryce Drew's 1998 buzzer-beater exemplifies this phenomenon.

Google CFO Patrick Pichette's retirement to prioritize family sparked debate about work/life balance.  While lauded, his choice, enabled by wealth, isn't attainable for most, highlighting the need for systemic workplace changes, not just individual solutions.

A.J. Pero, Twisted Sister's drummer for over 30 years, died of an apparent heart attack at 55.  Bandmates expressed devastation at the loss of their "brother" and praised his powerful drumming.  Pero was found unresponsive on his tour bus with Adrenaline Mob.

Mexican wrestler Hijo del Perro Aguayo died after a Rey Mysterio kick during a Tijuana match.  Delayed medical attention raised questions, and an investigation has been opened.  The wrestling world mourns the popular luchador.

Someone threatened to poison infant formula unless New Zealand stopped using 1080 poison for pest control.  While officials believe the threat is unlikely, security has been increased and an investigation is underway.

A racist chant by University of Oklahoma SAE members led to their suspension and the fraternity's expulsion from campus.  This incident follows a history of controversy for SAE, including hazing, alcohol violations, and other misconduct, leading to chapter closures and a "deadliest fraternity" label.

DC's Superman and Wonder Woman sport redesigned costumes and looks, with Superman going casual and Wonder Woman in pants and armor. Archie Andrews also gets a modern makeover for his upcoming TV show.  These changes mark a significant shift for these iconic characters.

Pre-election polls incorrectly predicted a tight race between Netanyahu and Herzog.  Netanyahu won decisively, likely due to flawed polling methodology, strategic voting, and a rightward shift consolidating right-wing votes.

An HBO documentary, "Montage of Heck," offers an intimate look at Kurt Cobain's life, featuring interviews with family and friends.  The film, premiering May 4th, includes a previously unheard 12-minute acoustic track and a companion book.

Negotiations with Iran regarding its nuclear program are ongoing, with a March 24 deadline approaching.  While progress has been made, gaps remain.  The U.S. and its negotiating partners are committed to preventing Iran from developing nuclear weapons.

Eleven service members, seven Marines and four Louisiana National Guardsmen, died in a Black Hawk helicopter crash.  They were dedicated servicemen, many with multiple deployments, including combat and disaster relief, leaving behind grieving families.

Republicans argue that the Iran nuclear deal is a treaty requiring Senate approval, while the Obama administration insists it's a nonbinding agreement.  This disagreement stems from differing interpretations of executive authority and the Constitution, with Republicans seeking to limit the deal's longevity.

BBC suspended "Top Gear" presenter Jeremy Clarkson for allegedly hitting a producer.  The next two episodes, and possibly a third, are cancelled.  Fans launched petitions both supporting and opposing Clarkson, who has a history of controversy.

Dolce & Gabbana's Milan Fashion Week show celebrated motherhood.  Models wore feminine, rose-adorned dresses featuring embroidered messages of love for "mamma," while real mothers and daughters formed a backdrop.  Even models carried children down the runway.

ISIS released a video showing a child executing 19-year-old Mohamed Musallam, claiming he was an Israeli spy.  Israel denies this, and Musallam's family says ISIS recruited and coerced him.  The video is another example of ISIS using children in propaganda and violence.

Following the police shooting and DOJ report exposing racial bias in Ferguson's police department, the article argues for police reform.  It emphasizes diversifying police forces, demilitarizing equipment, and prioritizing community policing to rebuild trust and address systemic issues.

Two Chinese men received prison sentences for selling military intelligence, including photos of the Liaoning aircraft carrier, to individuals posing as foreign journalists.  One man took photos at a military base and defense show, while the other sent hundreds of aircraft carrier pictures.

CBS released the first photos of Melissa Benoist as Supergirl in a costume designed by Colleen Atwood.  The pilot, starring Benoist, Calista Flockhart, and Mehcad Brooks, began production in Los Angeles and features a blend of classic and modern superhero elements.

Both Republicans and Hillary Clinton made avoidable mistakes this week, exacerbating political polarization.  Republicans' letter to Iran undermined negotiations, while Clinton's email handling reinforced distrust. Both actions hinder productive future politics.

UCF students created a nonprofit, Limbitless Solutions, using 3D printers to build low-cost bionic arms for children.  Twelve-year-old Wyatt, born with a missing forearm, will receive a custom-designed arm, inspiring him to help other children in the future.

The author contrasts traditional gender roles with their same-sex partnership, highlighting a more equitable division of labor.  They advocate for valuing domestic work, paying fair wages, and men actively participating in household chores to dismantle patriarchal norms and achieve true equality.

Larry David's hit Broadway play "Fish in the Dark" faces criticism for its stereotypical portrayal of a Hispanic maid, sparking debate about race and representation in theater, similar to the controversy surrounding NAAP's cancelled "Show Boat" production with an all-Asian cast.

Ben Stiller and Owen Wilson surprised Paris Fashion Week by reprising their "Zoolander" roles on the Valentino runway, promoting the upcoming "Zoolander 2" (February 2016).  Dressed in Valentino, they strutted their signature looks, Blue Steel included.

Following a racist video by SAE fraternity members, the University of Oklahoma is hiring a diversity VP.  Two students were expelled, and the fraternity chapter was closed.  Alumni admitted the chapter had problems for years.

Jeremy Clarkson's popularity allows him to weather controversies, even alleged physical assault.  He cultivates a victim persona, amplified by media attention, ensuring his fans defend him and his "bad boy" image boosts his celebrity status.

A racist fraternity video went viral, prompting University of Oklahoma President David Boren to swiftly condemn the students, sever ties with the fraternity, and expel members.  Boren's decisive action and moral clarity sparked national discussion about free speech, racism, and leadership.  He now aims to address the root causes of such behavior within the university.

In Jerusalem, a Palestinian driver injured four Israeli border police and a cyclist in a suspected terror attack.  The driver was shot by a security guard while attempting to flee and is severely wounded. Hamas praised the attack.

The National Gallery in London has banned selfie sticks, joining other museums like the Smithsonian and MoMA.  While supporting museum photography, #MuseumSelfieDay creator Mar Dixon agrees with the ban, citing personal space invasion and potential damage to art.

Republicans gained Congressional control promising effective governance, but instead manufactured a crisis by threatening a Department of Homeland Security shutdown over immigration policy, jeopardizing national security and vital services. This dysfunction highlights their focus on partisan politics over the middle class.

Cody Simpson, spokesman for the UN's #HappySoundsLike campaign, performs at SXSW to promote the International Day of Happiness.  He and other celebrities curated a playlist to spread happiness through music, emphasizing the importance of presence and simple joys.

At the Gridiron Club dinner, President Obama joked about marijuana legalization in D.C. and Hillary Clinton's private email server.  Scott Walker also attended, joking about Rudy Giuliani's comments on Obama's patriotism, which Obama countered with a birth certificate joke.

Chinese officials claim a 1,000-year-old mummified monk, discovered inside a Buddha statue in a Dutch museum, was stolen from China in 1995.  They are seeking repatriation of the statue, purchased by a private collector in 1996,  believed to be from a Fujian village temple.

Penn State's Kappa Delta Rho fraternity is suspended after a former member alerted police to a private Facebook page containing compromising photos of women, some possibly incapacitated.  The incident prompts a university investigation and re-evaluation of the fraternity system, echoing concerns raised after the Sandusky scandal.

CNN Student News for March 25, 2015, covered U.S. troop levels in Afghanistan, Israeli spying accusations, a French Alps plane crash, and a CNN Hero.  The transcript is available online, and schools can request a roll call mention.

Parisa Tabriz, Google's "Security Princess," leads a team of over 500 engineers protecting Chrome users from cyberattacks.  She proactively hacks Google's browser to find vulnerabilities before malicious actors do, combating threats ranging from individual hackers to government-sponsored surveillance.

A group claiming to be the "Islamic State Hacking Division" published online the alleged details of 100 U.S. troops, urging attacks against them.  Officials are investigating the threat's validity, but believe the information was likely gleaned from public sources.  Military personnel are being warned and advised to limit their online presence.

After a 14-year boycott due to alleged racial abuse, Serena Williams returned to Indian Wells.  She received a standing ovation and won her first match, calling her return a "huge win" regardless of tournament outcome.

Chuck Norris, the martial arts star and subject of countless tough-guy jokes, turned 75 (or maybe 39, because he defies time).  The article celebrates his birthday with humorous anecdotes about his invincibility.

After a 14-year boycott due to racist incidents, Serena Williams returns to Indian Wells.  Supported by her family, particularly her father and sister Venus, she aims to demonstrate strength and forgiveness.

Pi Day 2015 (3/14/15) offers an extended celebration of the mathematical constant.  Originating at San Francisco's Exploratorium in 1988, Pi Day festivities now include processions, pie eating, and even Einstein-themed events, as it coincides with his birthday.

Richard III's remains, found under a parking lot, revealed scoliosis, likely blond hair and blue eyes, a rich diet including heron, a roundworm infection, and battle wounds consistent with historical accounts of his death at Bosworth Field.

Tom Hanks delightfully lip-syncs to Carly Rae Jepsen's "I Really Like You" in her new music video.  Friends with Jepsen's manager, Hanks volunteered for the role, charmingly portraying himself interacting with fans and joining a flash mob with Jepsen and Justin Bieber.

A federal judge ordered the release of photos allegedly depicting detainee abuse in Iraq and Afghanistan. The government has 60 days to appeal. The ACLU sued for the photos' release, arguing they are crucial evidence of government misconduct.  The Pentagon opposes release, citing potential threats to Americans.

David Crosby struck a jogger with his car in Santa Ynez, CA.  Driving about 50 mph, Crosby, uninfluenced by drugs or alcohol, didn't see the jogger due to sun glare. The jogger sustained non-life-threatening fractures and was hospitalized. Crosby cooperated with authorities and expressed remorse.

U.S.-led coalition airstrikes have begun in Tikrit, Iraq, to support Iraqi forces fighting ISIS.  The strikes aim to weaken ISIS strongholds and enable Iraqi troops to retake the city, which fell to ISIS last June.

Denise Huskins, reported kidnapped from her boyfriend's Vallejo home, was found safe at her father's Huntington Beach apartment two days later.  Police are investigating the ransom kidnapping, and the FBI is involved.  Huskins' boyfriend is considered a witness and potential victim.

Former NFL star Darren Sharper pleaded guilty to sexual assault and attempted sexual assault in Arizona.  He received a nine-year prison sentence without early release and lifetime probation.  Sharper faced similar charges in multiple states.

A Germanwings Airbus A320 crashed in the French Alps, killing all 150 onboard.  The plane rapidly descended for eight minutes, but the controlled descent suggests a possible emergency landing attempt.  No distress call was made, prioritizing the "aviate, navigate, communicate" protocol.  The black box was recovered, and investigations are ongoing.

An American healthcare worker with Ebola, contracted while volunteering in Sierra Leone, will be treated at the NIH's biocontainment unit in Maryland. This is the second Ebola patient admitted to the NIH; the first, Nina Pham, recovered fully.

The VA is hindering veterans' access to local care promised by the Choice Act, narrowly interpreting the 40-mile rule.  Senator Moran proposes legislation to ensure veterans receive needed care, regardless of proximity to a VA facility, and criticizes the VA's inaction.

Angelina Jolie, carrying the BRCA1 gene mutation, underwent preventive surgery to remove her ovaries and fallopian tubes after a blood test showed potential cancer markers.  While facing forced menopause, she feels empowered by her decision, prioritizing her health and family.

BBC suspended "Top Gear" host Jeremy Clarkson after a fracas with a producer.  The show's upcoming episode was cancelled, sparking fan outcry and a reinstatement petition.  This incident follows past controversies involving racist language and a Falklands War number plate.

The Mormon Church defends its child abuse prevention efforts within Boy Scouts, despite lawsuits alleging insufficient action.  A case involving scoutmaster Vance Hein, previously removed from scouting, highlights failures in communication and background checks between the church and Boy Scouts.

J.K. Rowling, author of Harry Potter, responded to a fan who couldn't envision Dumbledore as gay.  Rowling's pointed reply: "Maybe because gay people just look like... people?"  Fans applauded her response.

Denise Huskins' reported kidnapping was a hoax, according to Vallejo police.  Huskins reappeared safe, stopped cooperating with authorities, and police now consider the $8,500 ransom demand unsubstantiated.  The investigation wasted significant resources and left the community on edge.

Rohana Rozhan, CEO of Astro Malaysia, a $4.6 billion media company, embodies fierce independence.  From a young age, she was driven to prove herself, leading her to oversee a company with 52% female employees, emphasizing merit and hard work.

Jon Hamm, star of "Mad Men," recently completed a 30-day rehab program for alcohol addiction at Silver Hill Hospital.  He entered treatment with the support of his partner, Jennifer Westfeldt, and they request privacy.  This comes shortly before the final episodes of "Mad Men" air.

Pastor Creflo Dollar is asking for $60 million in donations to buy a Gulfstream G650 jet. He claims his current, 30-year-old plane has had safety issues and the new jet is needed for his ministry's global travel.

A study of 130,000-year-old eagle talons found in Croatia suggests Neanderthals crafted jewelry and possibly possessed advanced hunting skills.  Markings on the talons indicate manipulation for ornamental purposes, challenging the simplistic view of Neanderthals.

Two University of Oklahoma students, Parker Rice and Levi Pettit, were expelled for their leading roles in a racist fraternity video.  Both are Dallas-area natives with athletic backgrounds.  They and their families have apologized, with friends and family claiming the video doesn't reflect their true character.

An 11-year-old boy dressed as Christian Grey from "Fifty Shades of Grey" for World Book Day.  His school deemed the costume inappropriate, modified it, and barred him from photos.  The mother argued it was less offensive than a teacher's Dexter costume.
In Washington state, a driver tried to use the HOV lane with a cardboard cutout of "The Most Interesting Man in the World."  The trooper, amused by the creative attempt, issued a $124 ticket.

Storms and tornadoes ripped through Oklahoma Wednesday, killing one and injuring two dozen.  A Sand Springs mobile home park was devastated, and a gymnastics studio was flattened.  Governor Fallin declared a state of emergency for 25 counties.

Republicans urge increased defense spending, citing Obama-era cuts as detrimental to military readiness and emboldening adversaries. They propose restoring funding to levels recommended by former Defense Secretary Gates, prioritizing threat assessment over arbitrary budget caps.

A massive winter storm spanning 2,000 miles from New Mexico to New England is impacting 94 million people.  Heavy snow, ice, and rain are causing travel disruptions, school closures, and flooding concerns.  Boston is nearing its record snowfall.

Two children's bodies were found in a freezer in a Detroit home during an eviction. Their mother was arrested on child abuse charges.  Two older siblings were taken into protective custody.  The cause of death is under investigation.

After a 10-day unexplained absence, sparking rumors about his health and power, Putin reappeared, dismissing the gossip.  He ordered military exercises, further asserting his control.  The Kremlin had denied any issues, attributing the absence to private meetings.

Jupiter's early migration inwards and outwards may explain our solar system's unique structure.  Its gravity pulled super-Earths into the sun, clearing the way for the formation of smaller, rocky planets like Earth from leftover debris.

Two Illinois cousins, one an Army National Guardsman, were arrested for plotting to support ISIS.  One planned to join ISIS in Egypt, while the other intended to attack a US military base in Illinois.  The plot was uncovered via an undercover FBI informant.

Jeremy Clarkson, controversial host of Top Gear, faced backlash for a Falklands War-referencing license plate in Argentina and various racist remarks, leading to his BBC suspension.  His "blokish humor" and politically incorrect commentary frequently sparked outrage.

A new biography, "Becoming Steve Jobs," offers a more sympathetic portrayal of the Apple co-founder than Walter Isaacson's earlier work.  Endorsed by Apple executives, it emphasizes Jobs' personal growth and leadership while downplaying his harsh demeanor.  Early reviews are mixed.

Taraji P. Henson apologized to Glendale police for claiming her son was racially profiled during a traffic stop.  Dashcam footage contradicted the claim, showing he was stopped for a traffic violation and cited for marijuana possession.  Henson admitted overreacting.

Viewers questioned the Germanwings crash, asking about the slow descent, lack of crash-prevention tech, absence of live cameras, hacking possibility, lack of explosion, and pilot drug testing frequency.  Experts addressed these concerns.

Gareth Bale's two goals propelled Wales to a 3-0 victory over Israel in Euro 2016 qualifying, securing their group lead.  Elsewhere, late goals salvaged draws for Italy against Bulgaria and the Czech Republic against Latvia.

Wait A Little safaris offers horseback riding tours through South African game reserves, using retrained racehorses.  These horses, accustomed to excitement, adapt well to encountering wildlife, providing a unique and thrilling safari experience, though not without risk.

On the eve of Nigeria's elections, the military announced the recapture of Gwoza, the town declared Boko Haram's caliphate headquarters.  This victory follows a six-week election delay due to security concerns and amidst ongoing violence and human rights abuses.

Post-election protests, including arson and gunfire, erupted in Rivers State, Nigeria.  The opposition alleges rigging and voter intimidation, demanding a cancellation, while the ruling party insists the election was credible.  Concerns rise about potential widespread violence as results are tallied.

Italy's high court definitively acquitted Amanda Knox and Raffaele Sollecito in Meredith Kercher's murder.  The Kercher family is disappointed, considering further legal action.  Sollecito may sue for wrongful imprisonment, while Knox likely won't due to her initial false statements.

Cyclone Pam devastated Vanuatu, leaving widespread destruction and homelessness.  The powerful storm flattened homes, destroyed crops, and disrupted essential services.  Aid is arriving, but the full extent of damage on outer islands remains unknown.

A bipartisan summit on criminal justice reform highlights a surprising alliance between progressives and conservatives.  Shared concerns about liberty, justice, and fiscal responsibility are driving efforts to reduce mass incarceration, finding common ground despite differences on other issues.

Zayn Malik has left One Direction due to stress. The remaining four members will continue as a group.  Fans expressed sadness online, while One Direction's music streams surged following the announcement.

Zayn Malik broke his silence after leaving One Direction, apologizing to fans and explaining he needed to be true to himself.  He felt unhappy continuing with the band and is now pursuing solo work, while One Direction will continue as a foursome.

The first "SPECTRE" trailer shows James Bond investigating a cryptic message and SPECTRE, a terrorist organization, linked to his past.  Featuring returning and new characters, the film promises a plot connected to "Skyfall" with hints revealed through a burnt photo and secret meetings.

Putin's unexplained absence fueled rumors and highlighted Russia's dependence on him.  The Kremlin's attempts to dispel rumors only amplified speculation about his health and a potential power vacuum in a system built entirely around his persona.

Charlottesville Police found no evidence supporting a Rolling Stone article detailing a UVA student's alleged rape at Phi Kappa Psi.  Discrepancies in the account led to a police investigation and an independent review of the article, with Rolling Stone issuing an apology.

Kylie Minogue will perform a 90-minute set at the Dubai World Cup on March 28th.  The event boasts $30 million in prize money, with the main race offering $10 million.  Minogue, worth an estimated $75 million, expressed excitement about performing at the prestigious horse racing event.

Thousands marched in Tunis to denounce terrorism after the Bardo Museum attack.  Tunisian and world leaders joined the demonstration, expressing unity against terrorism and declaring "We are not afraid."  Hours earlier, Tunisia announced the killing of the alleged attack mastermind.

Richard III's remains, found under a parking lot, will be reburied in a coffin crafted by his distant relative, Michael Ibsen.  The reburial, a grand procession through Leicestershire, aims to honor the king and offer a more dignified end than he received in 1485.

Senator Harry Reid's retirement paves the way for Chuck Schumer's likely leadership of Senate Democrats.  Schumer, with Reid's endorsement, ample funds, and political acumen, is well-positioned to lead, despite some left-leaning opposition.

Seven college-aged spring breakers were shot in Panama City Beach, Florida.  Police arrested a 22-year-old man for attempted murder.  Three victims were critically injured.  The city council held an emergency meeting to address the violence but voted down an alcohol ban.

A Germanwings Airbus A320 crashed in the French Alps, killing all 150 onboard.  The plane descended for eight minutes before crashing, suggesting some pilot control.  The cause is unknown, and recovery efforts are challenging due to the remote, mountainous terrain.

AMC's "Walking Dead" companion series is officially titled "Fear The Walking Dead."  A prequel set in Los Angeles, it follows new characters at the start of the zombie apocalypse.  Robert Kirkman and Dave Erickson co-created the series, premiering late summer 2015.

Undefeated Kentucky crushed West Virginia 78-39, advancing to the Elite Eight. Notre Dame and Wisconsin also won, while Arizona edged out Xavier. Kentucky's dominance continues, setting a record 37-0 start.

Lewis Hamilton secured pole position for the Malaysian Grand Prix ahead of Sebastian Vettel and teammate Nico Rosberg.  Despite heavy rain and a brief on-track disagreement with Rosberg, Hamilton dominated qualifying.  17-year-old Max Verstappen impressed with a sixth-place qualifying effort.

Yemen's President Hadi fled to Egypt as Saudi-led airstrikes against Houthi rebels intensified.  The Arab League largely supports the intervention, but civilian casualties are rising, and media outlets are under attack.  The US is providing logistical support.

In Los Angeles, a car collided with a commuter train near USC, derailing it and injuring 21 people. Ten were hospitalized, two with serious injuries.  The accident is expected to disrupt traffic for a soccer game at the nearby Coliseum.

Germanwings Flight 9525 crashed into the French Alps after co-pilot Andreas Lubitz locked the captain out of the cockpit and intentionally initiated an 8-minute descent. All 150 people aboard died instantly.  The passengers likely became aware of the situation in the final moments.

Jeremy Clarkson, suspended "Top Gear" host, received almost 1 million signatures supporting his reinstatement.  He expressed gratitude, while awaiting the BBC's internal investigation results. Clarkson's future remains uncertain after an altercation with a producer.

Montoursville, Pennsylvania, which suffered a similar tragedy 19 years ago, offers condolences to Haltern am See after the Germanwings crash.  They share their experience of grief, community support, and the long, painful journey of healing, offering any assistance they can provide.

Andreas Lubitz, the Germanwings co-pilot, deliberately crashed the plane, highlighting the unsettling truth that pilots, despite the image of superhuman professionalism, are fallible humans capable of extreme acts.  This tragedy shatters the illusion of perfect control in air travel.

CNN Student News on March 30, 2015, covered the Nigerian elections, an astronaut's 340-day ISS mission involving self-experimentation, and a fire-extinguishing sound wave invention.  The transcript is available online, and students 13+ can request a roll call mention.

Manchester United decisively beat Tottenham 3-0, solidifying their Champions League hopes and denting Tottenham's.  Rooney, Fellaini, and Carrick scored for United. Chelsea drew 1-1 with Southampton, maintaining their EPL lead. Real Madrid beat Levante 2-0 with two goals from Bale.

Thousands of Singaporeans braved torrential rain to mourn Lee Kuan Yew, their founding prime minister, who died at 91.  A state funeral, attended by global dignitaries, honored Lee's legacy of transforming Singapore into a prosperous nation, though his rule also drew criticism for limiting freedoms.

Houthi rebels seized Taiz airport and government buildings in Yemen, killing one and injuring 82.  The UN warned of impending civil war as the country spirals into chaos, with the US evacuating personnel.  The Houthis, who previously ousted the president, now control key areas amidst escalating violence and ISIS attacks.

A video surfaced of a University of Oklahoma fraternity house mother repeatedly saying the n-word.  While she and some black fraternity alumni claim she's not racist, the incident followed a video of fraternity members singing a racist song, leading to the chapter's closure and two expulsions.

A rare 475-pound juvenile leatherback sea turtle, Yawkey, was rescued in South Carolina, marking the state's first and the US's fifth such live rescue.  Found hypoglycemic but without injuries, it's recovering at the aquarium and will likely be released soon.

ISIS claimed responsibility for the Tunis Bardo Museum attack that killed 23, mostly foreign tourists.  Tunisian authorities arrested nine suspects, and while considered a local operation, it may signal ISIS's growing presence in Tunisia.

Nuclear talks with Iran are nearing a Tuesday deadline, but key issues like sanctions relief and R&D limits remain unresolved.  Israel's prime minister called the emerging deal "dangerous," while negotiators struggle to bridge differences before a potential Congressional intervention.

A jury found Robin Thicke and Pharrell Williams's "Blurred Lines" infringed on Marvin Gaye's "Got to Give It Up," awarding the Gaye family $7.4 million in damages and profits.  Though Thicke's credibility was questioned, the verdict highlights the blurry line between inspiration and infringement in music.

In 2014, over half the world's population lived in cities, a trend expected to rise to 66% by 2050.  African cities are experiencing rapid growth, with North African cities currently leading in infrastructure and human capital, while sub-Saharan cities show strong potential for future investment due to rapid population growth and diversity.

Trevor Noah will replace Jon Stewart as host of "The Daily Show."  Stewart, after 16 years, handpicked the South African comedian who debuted on the show in December.  Noah acknowledges the large shoes to fill, while Stewart expressed excitement for Noah and the show's future.

In Nigeria, "free readers associations" gather at newspaper stands, debating current events, especially during elections.  Vendors tolerate this, charging small, negotiable fees, as it attracts customers.  Though readership has declined due to internet access and economic hardship, these groups remain a social hub.

India's Supreme Court struck down Section 66A of the IT Act, which allowed arrests for "offensive" online content.  The court deemed it unconstitutional, violating freedom of speech.  The law's vague wording led to controversial arrests, sparking debate about online censorship.

Three Southern California school operators were arrested for a "pay-to-stay" visa fraud scheme.  They allegedly enrolled 1,500 foreign students, mostly from China and South Korea, who never attended classes, collecting $6 million in tuition.  The schools issued I-20 forms for student visas in exchange for $1,800.

Kate Middleton, the Duchess of Cambridge, made her final public appearances before maternity leave on Friday, visiting the Stephen Lawrence Centre and a church supporting youth charities in London.  She is expecting her second child with Prince William in mid- to late April.

The Germanwings crash, likely caused by the copilot's deliberate actions, highlights the unpredictable human element in aviation.  While mechanical failure is often investigated first, human factors, especially mental health, are crucial and require more rigorous screening and ongoing evaluations.

Sam Taylor-Johnson, director of "Fifty Shades of Grey," will not direct the sequels.  Citing an "intense" experience, she wished future directors success. The move follows reports of creative differences with author E L James, who holds significant control over the film adaptations.

Despite a dislocated shoulder from a recent fall, 85-year-old Arnold Palmer insists he will hit the ceremonial opening tee shot at the Masters on April 9, joining Jack Nicklaus and Gary Player.  He's not yet allowed to swing a club, but is determined to participate.

Iran and P5+1 are nearing a nuclear deal, but "important gaps remain."  While progress has been made on centrifuge numbers, sanctions relief and implementation timelines are sticking points.  Both sides face internal political pressures.

Millions of Chinese children are "left behind" in rural areas as parents migrate to cities for work due to economic hardship and the hukou system.  These children face educational struggles, mental health issues, and lack parental care, potentially creating a generation lacking security and trust.

Afghan President Ghani's US visit signals potential peace talks with the Taliban.  However, a successful agreement is unlikely given the Taliban's strength, Afghanistan's fragile unity government, and the risk of splinter groups.  The US can support the process by slowing troop withdrawals and bolstering the Afghan government.

Iraqi forces, backed by Shia militias and US airstrikes, have made significant gains in Tikrit, recapturing key buildings and neighborhoods.  They face resistance from ISIS, including numerous IEDs, but claim to have killed at least 26 militants.

Hillary Clinton faces controversy over private emails as Secretary of State.  Her strategy: attack accusers, wait out the media frenzy, and rally Democratic support by framing the issue as a partisan attack.  This playbook has worked for her before.

Facing expiring statutes of limitations, Swedish prosecutors offered to interview Julian Assange and collect his DNA at the Ecuadorian Embassy in London regarding 2010 sexual assault allegations.  Assange and his lawyer welcomed the offer, having requested it for years.

New Zealand beat South Africa in a thrilling rain-affected World Cup semi-final, reaching their first final. Grant Elliott's 84* and a final-ball six secured the win, chasing a revised target of 298. They'll face either Australia or India in the final.

Despite past suppression, Buddhism, particularly Tibetan Buddhism, is attracting young Chinese seeking spiritual grounding in a rapidly changing society.  While some embrace it as a lifestyle choice, others seek deeper religious commitment, finding solace in its practices and community.

In North Sinai, a truck bomb exploded at a security camp, killing the driver and one civilian, and injuring 42 soldiers and another civilian.  No group has claimed responsibility, but the region faces an ongoing Islamist insurgency.

Al-Shabaab attacked government offices in Baidoa, Somalia, killing nine, including four attackers.  A car bomb and heavy gunfire were involved.  Al-Shabaab claimed responsibility, stating they killed seven Ethiopian soldiers.  The African Union condemned the attack.

Canadian tennis star Eugenie Bouchard played doubles with pop star Justin Bieber at a charity tennis event in California.  Bouchard praised Bieber's serve on Twitter.  Fellow tennis player Caroline Wozniacki also posed with Bieber.

Despite strong opposition to a potential Iran nuclear deal, Israel's military response is unlikely.  An attack would have severe geopolitical consequences, damaging relations with allies and potentially sparking regional conflict.  Israel will likely focus on diplomatic pressure and intelligence gathering.

Kenya, the third largest flower exporter, supplies a significant portion of the EU's cut flowers.  Benefiting from ideal climate and transport links, the industry faces challenges like European economic fluctuations but is expanding to new markets.  Kenyan expertise is also fostering Rwanda's flower sector.

Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson hosted SNL with memorable skits like a vengeful Bambi and "The Rock Obama."  He then surprised Wrestlemania 31 fans by appearing with Ronda Rousey to confront WWE executives.

150 homeless people received a private tour of Vatican City, including the Vatican Museums, Sistine Chapel, and Vatican Gardens, organized by the Office of Papal Charities and led by Archbishop Krajewski.

The UK Supreme Court ruled to release Prince Charles's private letters to government officials, overturning government objections.  The Guardian, which pursued the case for a decade, celebrated the transparency victory, while the government and royal family expressed disappointment.

Kipling's "Law of the Jungle" faces modern challenges in India, where a growing human population clashes with dwindling tiger habitats.  While tiger-human conflict and poaching remain threats, conservation efforts, including conflict mediation, have led to a modest increase in tiger numbers.

Indiana's RFRA sparked controversy over potential LGBT discrimination.  While Governor Pence initially resisted changes, backlash forced him to seek a "fix."  Amendments could either establish statewide LGBT protections or exempt local anti-discrimination ordinances from the RFRA, but the latter is seen as undermining the law's intent.

Jordan Spieth won the Valspar Championship in a playoff, becoming the fourth golfer since 1940 with two PGA Tour wins before age 22.  He now sets his sights on Rory McIlroy's world No. 1 ranking, viewing the win as a boost of confidence heading into the majors.

CNN Student News for April 1, 2015, covered global events, US wage stagnation's economic impact, and the ethics of cyborg cockroaches for rescue missions.  The transcript is available online, and students 13+ can request a roll call mention.

Lewis Hamilton dominated the Australian Grand Prix, leading a Mercedes 1-2 finish ahead of teammate Nico Rosberg.  Sebastian Vettel secured third for Ferrari.  Several drivers retired, including Kimi Raikkonen and Max Verstappen, the youngest ever F1 driver.

Michael Douglas's son, Dylan, experienced anti-Semitism while wearing a Star of David.  This prompted Douglas to speak out against rising anti-Semitism, urging everyone to confront it and prevent its spread. He wants a better future for his son and future generations.

A 10th-century Anglo-Saxon "eyesalve" recipe from Bald's Leechbook, containing garlic, onion/leek, wine, and oxgall, has shown surprising effectiveness against MRSA in lab and mouse model tests, killing up to 90% of the bacteria.  Researchers are now exploring how this ancient remedy works.

Netanyahu backtracked on his pre-election rejection of a Palestinian state, but Palestinian negotiators remain skeptical and plan to pursue statehood through international bodies.  The US, expressing concern, will reassess its relationship with Israel.

Indiana's "religious freedom" law, allowing businesses to refuse service based on religious beliefs, has sparked heated debate.  Supporters cite religious liberty, while opponents decry discrimination, prompting boycotts and counter-arguments.  Businesses are divided, some vowing inclusivity despite the law.

Hans Haacke's "Gift Horse," a skeletal horse sculpture with a live stock ticker, is the latest installation on London's Fourth Plinth.  The artwork comments on art, commerce, and history, referencing an unrealized equestrian statue and Stubbs's anatomy studies. Public reaction is mixed.

Adam West and Burt Ward will reprise their roles as Batman and Robin in a 90-minute animated movie for the series' 50th anniversary in 2016.  Ward hinted at a possible second film.  Warner Bros. has not confirmed the project.

Nuclear talks with Iran in Lausanne were extended by a day past the initial deadline.  While progress was made, key sticking points remained on sanctions relief and the future of Iran's nuclear program.  A framework deal is hoped for, but not guaranteed.

BBC director-general Tony Hall received death threats, likely from outside the UK, following Jeremy Clarkson's dismissal from "Top Gear."  The threats arrived via email after Hall announced Clarkson's contract would not be renewed due to a physical and verbal altercation with a producer.

"Still Alice" winning an Oscar highlights the Alzheimer's crisis, especially impacting women.  Maria Shriver's "Wipe Out Alzheimer's" campaign urges women to fundraise, raise awareness, and advocate for research to combat this devastating disease.

A Canadian tourist, Jennifer Karren, died after a Cabo Adventures inflatable tour boat collided with a whale near Cabo San Lucas. Two others were injured.  Karren received CPR but died later in a hospital.  Mexican authorities are investigating.

Simone Gbagbo, Ivory Coast's former first lady, received a 20-year prison sentence for crimes against humanity related to the 2010 post-election violence.  Her husband, Laurent Gbagbo, awaits trial at the ICC for similar charges.

Donald Trump retrieved Rory McIlroy's club from a water hazard at Doral.  McIlroy used the club again, found the water again, and finished tied for ninth.  Dustin Johnson won the tournament, marking a successful return after a six-month break.

The incident came three years after Fabrice Muamba collapsed at White Hart Lane .

Two American women arrested for carving initials into a Colosseum wall .

Cambodia's Angkor Archeological Park experienced a string of nudity-related incidents this year .

It will be a first time for the tour stateside .
First show will be in Louisville, Kentucky .

A jihadist group claims responsibility in an audio recording, news agency reports .
The Malian government calls the shooting a "terrorist act"
One French citizen, one Belgian and three Malians are killed .

Cisse statement says: "I let you down"

The abducted workers were seized in an attack on an oil field last week .
They are from the Philippines, Bangladesh, Austria, the Czech Republic and Ghana .
Militants have carried out a series of attacks on oil fields in recent weeks .

Wichita, Kansas, high school students surprise principal with kind-hearted senior prank .
"This is why I do the things that I do," the principal says .

Comic book artist Norman Lee went missing in the Cayman Islands on Thursday .
Authorities called off search on Friday evening .

Use the Transcript to help students with reading comprehension and vocabulary .
At the bottom of the page, comment for a chance to be mentioned on CNN Student News.  You must be a teacher or a student age 13 or older to request a mention on the CNN Student News Roll Call.

Jeff Goldblum set to reprise his role in "Independence Day 2"
Liam Hemsworth and Jessie Usher also cast in key roles .
Sequel will be released 20 years after the original box office smash about an alien invasion .

Walter Mondale was released from the Mayo Clinic on Saturday, hospital spokeswoman said .
The former vice president, 87, was treated for cold and flu symptoms .

A man in suburban Boston is selling snow online to customers in warmer states .
For $89, he will ship 6 pounds of snow in an insulated Styrofoam box .

Jina Krause-Vilmar: On International Women's Day, focus on helping refugee women adapt to new lives .
She says aid agencies like hers aim to help these women build job skills and financial literacy .
She says the effort includes educating men about wives' and daughters' new roles .

Real Madrid slump to defeat against Athletic Bilbao .
Solitary goal from Aritz Aduriz enough to give the Basques victory .
Bayern Munich continue Bundesliga domination .

Police in Japan say they have arrested a man, 40, after five neighbors were fatally stabbed .
The accused shares the same surname as the victims, aged 59 to 84, local media say .
A police official says the man has admitted to the stabbings but refused to comment further .
Car bomb detonated near police vehicle in Lashkar Gah, deputy governor says .

The terror attacks in India left more than 160 people dead .
A  court granted the suspect bail last year .

Police: Officer fired two shots when the man charged at him .
The case was immediately turned over to the GBI .

A photo of a green woodpecker flying with a weasel on its back has gone viral on Twitter .
The image was snapped by amateur photographer Martin Le-May near London .
It sparked the hashtag #weaselpecker and has spawned numerous memes .

A wag decided to sell "air from Kanye West concert" on eBay .
Bidding got to more than $60,000 before plug was pulled .
Others are now doing similar auctions .

Delta Air Lines Flight 1086 skidded into a fence last week at a LaGuardia Airport beset by winter weather .
The NTSB says the crew reported they did not sense any deceleration from the wheel brake upon landing .

More than 100 schools renamed in honor of students killed in a Taliban schoolhouse attack .
A six-hour siege at a Peshawar school killed 145 people in December .

#thedress was an Internet sensation: Is it blue and black or white and gold?
The Salvation Army in South Africa is using it to raise awareness .
The reaction has been mostly positive .

The lack of charges against Busch expedited the decision, a NASCAR official says .
Kurt Busch was accused of grabbing his ex-girlfriend by the throat, slamming her head .
He twice appealed NASCAR's indefinite suspension and lost .

Interim report exposes delays and inaction after MH370 disappeared .
Flight carrying 239 people and crew has not been found, one year later .
Took 10 hours for the first search flights to take off, according to report .

167 people have been rescued, Myanmar's government says .
The ferry capsized after being hit by a large wave in bad weather conditions .

China sends fighter jets to patrol over border with Myanmar following the incident .
Report: In addition to the fatalities, nine others were wounded .

According to a Pew report, 80% of Internet users have looked up health info online .
Sites like Mayo Clinic and others curated by doctors are safer than online forums .

Erich Nowsch will face three charges, including first-degree murder .
He is accused of killing Tammy Meyers in front of her home .
The two lived withing walking distance of each other .

Latest Ferguson shootings push strained race relations to breaking point .
Donna Brazile: Relationship between police forces and minority communities must improve .

North Korea apologizes to Bangladesh after one of embassy's diplomat caught with 59 pounds of gold .
Gold was undeclared, says Bangladeshi government .

Baby Lily was trapped in the car in the cold river for as long as 14 hours .
"She knows everything she knew before anything happened. It's amazing," father says .
Lily's mother, Lynn Jennifer Groesbeck, died in the crash .

The chopper was registered to an air ambulance company .
It was en route from Tulsa to McAlester .

A Californian startup has developed a circular smartphone called "Runcible"
The provocative anti-phone is meant to be an antidote to our obsession for digital devices .

Official "Star Wars" universe gets its first gay character, a lesbian governor .
The character appears in the upcoming novel "Lords of the Sith"
Characters in "Star Wars" movies have gradually become more diverse .

The Pakistani Taliban claims responsibility for the suicide bombings .
